div.p:
I have just received the account which
you enclosed to me, instead of to my brothers
- Lovell & Sneyd -- to whom, as to the Executors
it properly ought to have been directed
I am however glad that it was sent to
me, as it gives me an opportunity of tell
ing telling you my sentiments respecting one
particular in that account which I
must request to have altered, before it
goes into my brother's hands. --

You charge the printing &c - of the second
edition of my father's Essay on wheel
carriages and you admit no copyright
for that work -- This I cannot think
just or feel to be properly respectful
to his memory & talents. -

I am well aware, that the book in
question is not like books of mere amuse
=ment amusement , immediately profitable to a pub-
lisher publisher , but a publisher such as it becomes
the successor of Mr. Johnson to prove him
-self himself ought to take the future as well as
the present into his account - and should
consider the solid value & consequent
permanent tho' perhaps slow advan
=tage advantage - likely to accrue from any publica-
tion publication . Now without presuming myself
to judge of a work of science of which
I am ignorant, & setting aside as far as
it is in my power, my feelings as his
daughter, friend & literary partner --
I do firmly believe from all I have
heard said, & seen written about the Essay
on Wheel carriages by those who are res-
=pected respected the best judges on the subject at
home & abroad, that the book is highly es= esteemed

teemed esteemed & is likely to last & to rise & fix
itself in public estimation -. consequently
I must believe that it is at least worthy
the expense of printing & any risk you
may run from the slowness of sale, Indeed
I did not conceive it possible that no copy
right had, or would be offered by you for
it --

I was so much surprised by the charge
to which I allude in your account that I
immediately conceived it must have
been by some special request of my
fa-
-thers father's
in some letter of which which I ei-
-ther either had not seen, or had forgotten.
He kept copies of all his letters to you and
before I answered you last - I felt it best
justice to you, to look over every one of
these for the last two years. -- It has been
a very painful task, for reasons which I
need not explain to you. -- I endeavor not to
mine sentiment or my own private feel-
=ings feelings with business because they have
nothing to do with each other --

I do not find in any of his letters any ex

conceived or intended you should print this
2d.
edt.
edition of his work at his expense or that
you would not offer him any renumera
=tion renumeration for it - One or other I think ought
to be done - If I do not mistake entirely
in my judgment of your character it can
=not cannot - when you have read so far in my
letter occur to you Sir, to suspect that the thirty
points in question is my object - You are
at liberty to charge the same sum in any
form but this, which both hurts my feelings
as a daughter and my sense of justice -
I observe that you have not charged the ex-
pense expense of reprinting two cancelled sheets of
Ormond - my father requested that this
shd
should
be charged to our acct.
account - And I likewise beg
that you will charge the additional ex=
pense expense to which I am aware you must have
been put by hurrying to oblige me - the printing
of
Haron. Harrington & Ormond. - Believe me I am as grateful
for those exertions as I was at the time I so
anxiously urged them. - You will not find
that you I shall object to any thing that you
may name in this account. Therefore you com-
=prehend comprehend that I do not desire to lessen my debt
to you, but simply to cancel an offensive & substitute a

charge that will be entirely agreeable
to me --

Be so good to charge all the presentation
copies of Dramas & Harrington & Ormond
which were above the usual number
allowed --

In your note to me you say that at Mi-

for the copy right of Comic Dramas --
But I find in one of my dear just fath
fathers father's
letters that he particularly
says that he should not call for this mo-
ney money till the 7th. May being a year after
the publication of those Dramas. -- Of
course I shall do as he would have
done --
